newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa plans listing of state energy assets.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa plans listing of state energy assets.

text.p: South Africa planned to consolidate all state-owned energy assets into a major company to be listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, Minerals and Energy Minister Penuell Maduna said.
Maduna told parliament late on Wednesday that the assets of the Central Energy Fund (CEF) and other energy-related interests held by state institutions would be formed into one integrated company.

Maduna said he aimed "to list the new company on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange as and when appropriate, as a mechanism for recovering and restoring value to government through (the) sale of a significant minority of the share equity".

He said the government's energy-related assets were scattered among several state entities, including shares in energy company Sasol Ltd held by the state's Industrial Development Corporation and state-owned liqued fuels transporter Petronet included in railways company Transnet.

"There is now an opportunity to unite, consolidate and restructure these assets into a strategically synergistic vehicle based on the disparate elements both within and oudside of the CEF," Maduna said.
Maduna said a significant minority of the new company would be sold to South African black empowerment groups.
He added that the new company would assist in formulating a Pan-African energy strategy based on using the South African capital market to maximise value for all concerned parties.

"The objective is to transform the CEF group into a more conventional united public holding company, which will proceed to evolve and develop a comprehensive South African energy profile and a leadership role in the energy sector both at home and within a Pan-African context," Maduna said.
